data.title: Quicksand (2023)
data.meta_description: A married couple on the brink of divorce becomes trapped in quicksand while hiking through a Colombian rainforest. It’s a struggle for survival as they battle the elements of the jungle and must work together in order to escape.
data.text:
Score : 4.8/10 ✅

Built around the idea that it should be exciting to see two people be condemned in sinking sand. The reality is more like the opposite. It’s not particularly amazing but I must say this: it was decently watchable.

As with most ‘one location’ setting, it’s an enforced method to make them feel vulnerable while making them overcome adversity in various ways. We are looking at the classical case where we are learning something from their past, so no surprise here. However, Quicksand fails to deliver the despair and the ‘clock is ticking’ aspect that makes those thrillers interesting. You are just realizing that you are looking at a soon-to-be-divorced couple going through the same (and only) escape route for 45 minutes straight.

The ending is also straightforward, which I can appreciate, but a bit too calculated.

"All we did was go on a hike, now we're stuck in fucking quicksand!" - actual dialogue/full plot summary

I'd be surprised this wasn't from the producers of "47 Meters Down" and "Fall" since it's stealing their fill-in-the-blank high-concept script template every step of the way, except this movie has no idea how to goose any latent fear of the natural threat, so I don't want to insult those fine people behind some of my favorite gimmick thrillers of recent times. Competency courses through "Quicksand" - it's filmed just fine, has a modicum of foggy rainforest atmosphere, the actors aren't bad, everything makes sense, it's an inoffensive attempt at dreaded metaphorror (accentuating mopey psychological themes over any horror mechanics, in…
